title-group.article-title: Thermosensitive poly(N-isopropyl acrylamide-co-N,N-dimethyl acryl amide)-block-poly(d,l-lactide) amphiphilic block copolymer micelles for prednisone drug release

abstract.p: Novel amphiphilic block copolymers consisting of hydrophobic poly(D,L-lactide) segments and hydrophilic poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-N, N-dimethylacrylamide) blocks were designed and synthesized through a simple free radical copolymerization route based on a bifunctional initiator, followed by the ring-opening polymerization of D,L-lactide. The copolymers self-assembled into thermosensitive spherical-nanosized core–shell micelles in aqueous solution in the presence or the absence of the model drug prednisone. The chemical and physical characterizations of drug-loaded and unloaded micelles revealed a lower critical solution temperature of 40°C–47°C, and a critical micelle concentration less than 7.20 mg L−1, a transmission electron microscope mean particle size from 50 to 75 nm, and a narrow dynamic light scattering diameter below 180 nm. The prepared blank and drug-loaded micellar nanoparticles were thermodynamically stabile and employed in targeted drug delivery by responding to the higher temperature of the local microenvironment. Based on prednisone release kinetic studies, structural changes of the self-assembled micelles as well as temperature- or environment-induced diffusion controlled drug release and improved bioavailability. The copolymer micelles exhibited good biocompatibility as established by the MTT cytotoxicity assay. Therefore, an effective target therapy against lesion tissues is feasible using these polymeric micelles.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, amphiphilic block copolymers composed of hydrophobic blocks and hydrophilic blocks have attracted considerable attention in polymer science research.1–4 The interest in amphiphilic block copolymers stems from their ability to self-assemble into highly ordered supramolecular nanostructures in aqueous media through hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interactions, hydrophobic interactions, and van der Waals forces.2,5–7 They have been utilized as nanoreactors,8,9 nanotemplates, and nanocarriers.10–13 The amphiphilic nanocarriers are especially suited as a new type of drug release carrier1,2,10,11 due to their structural stability, excellent tissue permeability, long drug residence times, and effective targeting. Improving targeting performance and decreasing the initial burst release have become the focus of recent research.14

In general, the composition of the copolymers, as well as the chemical nature of each block, plays a decisive role in their self-assembly. Therefore, the behavior of amphiphilic block copolymers can be controlled by the adjustment of the composition and synthetic design. Lu et al.10 developed amphiphilic polysaccharide derivatives by coupling dextran and poly(ϵ-caprolactone) capped with phenylalanine. The in vitro release of indomethacin from these micelles exhibited a diffusion-controlled drug release behavior without a burst effect. Amphiphilic scorpion-like macromolecules were also studied as potential candidates for intracytoplasmic and nuclear delivery of drugs, proteins, and/or gene nanocarriers.11

The properties of the amphiphilic block copolymer micelles are often affected by changes in the solubility of one of the blocks, by pH,15–17 temperature,14,17 ionic strength,18,19 as well as complexation with other building blocks.4 Luo et al.16 also reported a polyion complex (PIC) micelle consisting of poly(N-vinylpyrrolidone)-block-poly(2-acrylamido-2-methyl-1-propane sulfonic acid) for folic acid release, which exhibited good pH sensitivity and biocompatibility. Poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (PNIPAM) is a well-known temperature-responsive polymer that has a reversible temperature-induced phase transition. PNIPAM adopts an extended coil conformation below the low critical solution temperature (LCST, about 32°C–33°C),20,21 and a globular conformation above the LCST due to dehydration in aqueous media.22–24

Many amphiphilic block copolymers based on PNIPAM have been reported, including polystyrene and poly(butyl methacrylate),25 poly(butyl methacrylate),26 poly(amino acid),27 poly(methyl methacrylate),28 and polyurethane.29 Poly(D,L-lactide) (PLA) has been introduced into the polymers as a hydrophobic biodegradable component for structural stability.30 In order to realize active targeting in the body as drug carriers, the LCST of the thermosensitive blocks should be above normal body temperature (37°C). By incorporating a hydrophilic comonomer, such as N,N-dimethylacrylamide (DMAM), at proper composition, the LCST was adjusted to guarantee that these thermosensitive micelles flow within the blood stream at normal body temperature and aggregate at the tumor site for effective therapy.14,31,32 Gan et al.17 synthesized amphiphilic ABC triblock copolymers, methoxypoly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(N-isopropylmethacryl-amide-co-acrylic acid)-b-poly(methyl methacrylate). The copolymers self-assemble into thermoresponsive nanosized micelles at various LCSTs in aqueous media by changing pH for “intelligent” drug delivery systems.

In this article, our aim is to synthesize a thermotriggered amphiphilic block copolymer consisted of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-N,N-dimethylacrylamide) (P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)) block and PLA via a bifunctional initiator followed by ring-opening polymerization and to examine their self-assembly micellar behavior and influence of the environmental temperature on the drug release behavior. The cytotoxicity measurements are performed to prove potentials of the polymer micelles as nanosized carriers for intravenous injection and oral drug delivery.

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p: Material NIPAM (98%) was kindly provided by the Aladdin Reagent Company (Shanghai, China) and was recrystallized from n-hexane. DMAM (99.5%, Alfa Aesar GmbH & Co., Heysham, England, KG) was used without further purification. D,L-lactide (Shenzhen BrightChina Industrial Co. Ltd., Shenzhen, China) was purified by recrystallization from ethyl acetate. 2, 2′-Azobis (2-methylpropionamidine) dihydrochloride (AMAD, Wake Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd, Japan) and stannous octoate (Sn(Oct)2; Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China) were used as received. Tetrahydrofuran (THF) and xylene (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd) were dried over CaH2 and distilled before use. N, N-Dimethyl Formamide (DMF, 99.5%, Alfa Aesar GmbH & Co. KG) was used without further purification. All other chemicals were of analytical grade and used directly, unless otherwise specified.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The synthesis of thermosensitive poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-N,N-dimethylacrylamide)-block-poly(D,L-lactide) (P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA) copolymers was achieved using our two-step process.33 Briefly, NIPAM and DMAM were dissolved in 25 mL THF in line with the mass ratios of NIPAM to DMAM 100/0, 90/10, 80/20, and 70/30. The bifunctional initiator AMAD (2 wt% of the monomers) was introduced, and dried nitrogen was bubbled through the solution for 30 min. The polymerization proceeded at 80°C for 10 h, and the hydroxyl-terminated P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH was obtained by precipitation in excess diethyl ether, filtration, and vacuum drying at room temperature. The –OH chain ends were formed from bifunctional initiator residues according to free radical polymerization mechanism.33 The Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR): ν (cm−1) = 1647 (C═O, amide I), 1546 (–NH, amide II), 3304 and 3430 (–NH and terminal –OH), and 1397 (C–N). 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) = 2.92 (s, –N(CH3)2), 2.07 (t, –CH–CH2– in main repeating units), 1.13 (d, –NHCH(CH3)2), 3.99 (m, –NHCH(CH3)2), 6.65 (m, –NHCH(CH3)2), 4.14 (m, weak, –CONHCH2CH2OH), 3.64 (m, weak, –CONHCH2CH2OH), and 2.76 (t, weak, –CH2CH2OH, –OH end group).

The P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH precursors were used to synthesize P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA copolymers in the presence of D,L-lactide as a monomer by ring-opening polymerization reaction. All monomers and precursors were dried before use. Specifically, a predetermined amount of the precursor and D,L-lactide was added into a 50-mL three-neck flask containing 20 mL of dry xylene with stirring.

A catalytic amount of Sn(Oct)2 was added into the mixture and nitrogen bubbled for 30 min before polymerization. The reaction was carried out at 135°C for 24 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The resulting polymers were purified by precipitating twice with diethyl ether and dried in a vacuum oven at 30°C for 48 h until constant weight. No –OH proton shift from carboxyl-terminated groups of PLA (HOOCCH(CH3)O–) at 12–12.5 ppm confirms that there is no PLA homopolymers in the sample. The P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymer power was stored for further use. FT-IR: ν (cm−1) = 1753 (C=O from PLA chains), 1093–1127 (C–O from PLA), 1647 (C=O, amide I), 1546 (ν –NH–, amide II), and 3304 and 3430 (–OH in PLA and –NH). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) = 2.92 (s, –N(CH3)2), 2.31 (t, –CH–CH2– in main repeating units), 1.13 (d, –NHCH(CH3)2), 3.99 (m, –NHCH(CH3)2), 6.65 (m, –NHCH(CH3)2), 1.55 (d, –OOCCH(CH3)O–), and 5.06 and 5.21 (m, –CH(CH3)– in the PLA blocks).

sec.title: Copolymer characterization
sec.p: NMR spectrometer (Bruker Avance, 300 MHz, Bruker Corp., Germany) was used to confirm the chemical structure of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH and P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA. 1H NMR spectra were obtained in CDCl3 with tetramethylsilane as internal standard and D2O (chemical shifts were calibrated as zero standard). FT-IR of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH and P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymers and copolymer micelles was characterized in the range of 4000–400 cm−1, which were recorded on an AVATAR 360 ESP FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet, USA) from samples pressed in KBr pellets. The molecular weight and polydispersity index (PDI) of polymers were determined by gel permeation chromatography (GPC, Waters, USA) equipped with Waters 717 Plus Autosample (Waters Corp., USA), 1515 Isocratic HPLC Pump (Waters Corp., USA), and 2414 Refractive Index Detector (Waters Corp., USA). Chromatographic grade THF was used as solvent at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1 at 35°C and narrow disperse polystyrene as calibration standards. The samples were dissolved in THF, and the copolymer solutions were filtered through a 0.45 µm (pore size) needle-type filter (organic, diameter: Φ13 mm) and afterward injected into sample bottles for the measurement.

sec.title: Preparation and characterization of the polymer micelles
sec.p: The P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH and P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA micelles were prepared by a dialysis method according to their solubility in aqueous solution. A solution of block polymer (40 mg) in DMF (10 mL) was dialyzed (Mw cutoff = 8000–14000 g mol−1) against 1000 mL distilled water or pH = 1.4 and 7.4 phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) solution at room temperature with vigorous stirring. The dialysis was run for 2 days in order to remove DMF completely. The water or PBS solution was replaced every hour for the first 5 h and then at 24 h. Of course, some possible soluble precursors or a small amount of samples with low molecular weight would loose their mass during dialysis.

sec.title: Determination of critical micelle concentration
sec.p: For the physical properties and stability of block copolymer micelles in aqueous solution, the critical micelle concentration (CMC) was obtained by surface tension. The surface tension was recorded on a DCAT21 tensiometer (DataPhysics, Germany) at room temperature. A series of the sample aqueous solutions with concentrations from 5 × 10−5 to 1 × 10−1 mg mL−1 were maintained overnight prior to the measurement and were determined individually by the Wilhelmy plate method. The CMC value was evaluated from plots of the static surface tension versus the logarithm of the concentrations.

sec.title: Cloud point determination
sec.p: For the thermosensitive polymer micelles, the cloud point or LCST was obtained by recording the optical transmittance of the micelle solutions (250 mg L−1) in various media at a wavelength of 500 nm versus temperature. The process was implemented using a U-3900 Hitachi UV-vis spectrophotometer (Hitachi Corp., Japan) equipped with an electronic thermostatic cell holder and a temperature controller. The heating rate was set at 0.5°C min−1, and the apparatus was calibrated using deionized water at room temperature. The cloud point temperature was defined as the temperature producing a half decrease of the total decrease in transmittance.

sec.title: Transmission electron microscope observations
sec.p: Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to determine the morphology and size of the blank and drug-loaded polymer micelles. The samples were prepared by placing a drop of micelle solutions on the copper grid with carbon films and staining with 2 wt% phosphotungstic acid aqueous solution before measurements. All TEM images were obtained at an accelerating voltage of 200 keV using a JEM-2100 TEM (JEOL, Japan).

sec.title: Dynamic light scattering measurements
sec.p: The mean diameter and size distribution of the blank and drug-loaded P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA micelle particles at 250 mg L−1 in different media were measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS, BI-90Plus, USA) equipped with an argon ion laser operating at λ = 660 nm. All the measurements were performed at 25°C and 45°C, and at a fixed scattering angle of 90°, unless noted otherwise.

sec.title: Zeta potential
sec.p: The zeta potentials of block copolymer micelle in dilute solutions of 100 mM PBS (pH 7.4) were measured by Nano Particle Analyzer (Delsa Nano S; Beckman Coulter, USA) at 25°C. Each measurement was performed three times.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) thermal analyses of polymers and freeze-dried prednisone-loaded micelles were performed on a Q1000DSC + LNCS + FACS Q600SDT thermoanalyzer system (TA Corp., USA) at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 under a purged nitrogen atmosphere (40 mL min−1).

sec.title: X-ray diffraction measurements
sec.p: An X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu radiation, λ = 0.15418 nm) measurements were recorded using a Rigaku diffractometer (D/Max2550VB+/PC; Rigaku Corp., Japan) running at 40 kV and 40 mA to acquire information about drug encapsulation.

sec.title: Cytotoxicity studies and bioactivity of the drug after loading
sec.p: The cytotoxicity of the blank block copolymer micelles, free prednisone, and prednisone-loaded micelles was assessed with methyl thiazolyl tetrazolium (MTT) viability assay against L929 mouse embryonic fibroblasts. Cells were seeded into a 96-well plate at a density of 1 × 104 cells per well, cultured overnight, and then incubated with (blank or drug-loaded) polymeric micelles of various concentrations in a complete Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) containing 10% hyclone fetal bovine serum (FBS) (high glucose DMEM) at 37°C in 5% CO2 atmosphere for 24 h before assay. To determine the cytotoxicity of free prednisone, blank micelles or drug-loaded micelle solutions with the concentration range from 10 to 800 mg L−1 in complete DMEM were used to replace the culture medium, and the cells were further cultured for 24 h. After culture for 72 h, the medium was replaced by 100 µL of fresh DMEM, followed by adding 20 µL of MTT stock solution (5 mg mL−1) to the fibroblasts. After incubation for an additional 4 h, the supernatant was discarded, and then 150 µL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was added and shaken for 10 min at room temperature. At the same time, cells were seeded in a fresh culture medium (negative control) under the same conditions for reference purposes. The optical density (OD) was monitored at 490 nm by a 96-well universal microplate reader (Model 680; Bio-Rad Laboratories Ltd, UK), and the relative cell viability was calculated using the following equation

where ODcontrol was obtained in the absence of free prednisone, blank micelles, or drug-loaded micelles, and ODsample was obtained in the presence of free prednisone, blank micelles, or drug-loaded micelles.

The bioactivity of the drug after loading was measured in line with the study by Liu et al.34 via plating efficiency (PE) versus prednisone concentration for the L929 cells treated with free prednisone or prednisone-released from micelles. Student’s t-test was used to determine the significance of any pairs of observed differences. Differences were considered statistically significant when p < 0.05. All quantitative results are reported as mean values ± standard deviation from data obtained from at least three separate experiments.

sec.title: Preparation of prednisone-loaded micelles and in vitro release
sec.p: P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA copolymer (20 mg) and prednisone (20 mg) were dissolved in 5 mL DMF. Distilled water was added dropwise to the polymer and prednisone solution with vigorous stirring overnight at room temperature to induce micelle formation. The samples were transferred to dialysis bags (Mw cutoff = 8000–14000 g mol−1) and against 1000 mL distilled water for 24 h. The dialyzate was lyophilized, and the prednisone-loaded micelle samples were stored for further use.

The prednisone-loaded micelle samples were dispersed in distilled water or PBS solution at a concentration of 1 mg mL−1. Aliquots of the solution (5 mL) were transferred to dialysis tubes and then immersed separately into 500 mL distilled water or PBS solution at 25°C, 37°C, and 45°C. Aliquots of 5 mL were withdrawn from the solution periodically. The volume of solution was kept constant by adding 5 mL of distilled water or PBS solutions after each sampling. The amount of prednisone released from the micelles was measured using ultraviolet (UV) absorbance at 240 nm. M0 was estimated from the data obtained during the drug-loading stage by subtracting the amount of prednisone not loaded into the micelles from the feed prednisone amount of 20 mg. The amount of unloaded drug was analyzed by measuring the absorbance of the dialyzate at 240 nm after drug loading. It was found that around 69.03 wt% of the feed drug, prednisone, was loaded into the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA micelles.

sec.title: Synthesis and characterization of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymers
sec.p: A series of hydroxyl-terminated P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH was prepared by free radical copolymerization based on a bifunctional initiator AMAD with an average yield up to approximate 90%. The hydroxyl terminal groups were used to synthesize thermosensitive P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA amphiphilic block copolymers by the ring-opening polymerization of D,L-lactide in the presence of Sn(Oct)2 catalyst. Their structures were characterized by FT-IR and 1H NMR. The influence of mass ratios of NIPAM to DMAM as well as the precursor to D,L-lactide on the polymerization reaction was investigated by change in molecular weight determined by GPC. The detailed sample codes and the experimental results are summarized in Table 1. For instance, sample A with a mass ratio of NIPAM to D,L-lactide of 90:10 and the precursor to D,L-lactide of 1:2 is defined as P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12. The subscripts in P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12 represent the system feed ratios. Other samples can be defined by analogy.

sec.p: The molecular weight of the copolymers changed with the system composition. When the mass ratios of NIPAM to DMAM were lower than 80:20, the number-average molecular weight (Mn) is slightly increased with increasing the feed ratios of DMAM to NIPAM, but decreased with further increasing the ratio (70:30). The P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA copolymers exhibit similar trends to P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-OH at an identical ratios of NIPAM to DMAM (samples A–C and F). For P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA copolymers with the same ratios of precursor to D,L-lactide, the Mn is decreased as the PLA mass ratios are decreased (samples C–E). The high PDI values of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA copolymers in the range from 1.30 to 1.60 are dependent upon the free radical polymerization mechanism.33 Although the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA copolymers have high PDI values in the range from 1.30 to 1.60, they are anticipated to be used as drug release carriers. Similar delivery platforms using this type of polymers with a wide molecular weight distribution can be found in the literature.14,32,33

sec.title: Formation and characterization of polymeric micelles
sec.p: Based on the unique chemical structure of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymers, they can self-assemble into core–shell micelles in aqueous solution at room temperature. The hydrophobic PLA chains have good biocompatibility and can aggregate to form the micelle core, while the thermoresponsive P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) precursor forms the micelle shells. The CMC values of a series of the copolymer micelles are presented in Table 2. As a whole, the block copolymers have considerably low CMC values from about 5.51 to 7.19 mg L−1.

sec.p: This indicated that the block copolymer micelles may be stable enough to withstand intravenous injection into a large volume of blood and could be used as controlled drug release vehicles. Further investigations reveal that the more hydrophilic DMAM units and the mass fractions or block lengths of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) and PLA have effects on the CMC. All the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-containing copolymers had relatively high CMC values compared with the PNIPAM containing due to better hydrophilicity of the comonomer DMAM than NIPAM. The CMC values increased with increasing the DMAM mass fractions; however, increasing the mass ratios of the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82 to PLA, the CMC values were slightly decreased from 6.87 to 5.79 mg L−1. The micellization of the block copolymers in aqueous milieu can also be proven by FT-IR spectra, as shown in Figure 1. To obtain P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-PLA block copolymer micelles for FT-IR analysis, the dialyzate (800 mg L−1) was freeze-dried for 2 days. The absorption peak at 1753 cm−1 that represented the ester carbonyl characteristics in PLA blocks disappears in the copolymer micelles, compared with that in the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-PLA block copolymer powder sample, indicating the formation of a core–shell micellar structure with hydrophobic PLA blocks as cores wrapped up by hydrophilic chains. On the other hand, the amide C=O peak in P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) shells in the copolymer micelles spectrum was as strong as that in the spectrum of the block copolymers that inferred that the block copolymers formed a core–shell micellar structure with isolated hydrophobic PLA inner cores and hydrophilic P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) outer shells at room temperature.

sec.title: Thermoresponse of the block copolymer micelles
sec.p: PNIPAM is a thermosensitive polymer and exhibits a LCST or cloud point around 32°C–33°C in aqueous solution, lower than the normal body temperature of 37°C. This unique temperature sensitivity of PNIPAM is believed to hinge on a critical hydrophilic/hydrophobic balance between the chemical groups on the polymers. To make thermoresponsive micelles suitable for biomedical applications, it is necessary to increase the LCST to a desired temperature range above normal body temperature by copolymerization with a more hydrophilic comonomer. As shown in Table 2, another hydrophilic monomer DMAM was introduced into the PNIPAM backbone to increase the LCST phase transition temperature of the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymer micellar solutions to the range of 40.0–46.6°C.20,35,36 Further examinations reveal that the LCST values depend on the copolymer compositions. Increasing the mass ratio of hydrophilic DMAM to thermosensitive NIPAM as well as that of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) to PLA increased the LCST values of the copolymer micelle solutions. It seems that the more hydrophilic chains participated in hydrogen bonding interactions between copolymer molecules and water, thereby, weakening the intra- and/or intermolecular hydrophobic interactions between the PNIPAM chains. The change in the LCST values is expected to be applicable to lesion tissue applications like tumor or inflammation where the temperature is above the normal body temperature. P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymer micelles with low CMC and tunable thermosensitive response (adjustable LCST values) can encapsulate anticancer or anti-inflammation drugs and remain stable during systemic circulation. As they arrive at lesion sites, like tumor or inflammation, the higher temperature will change the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) shell from hydrophilic to hydrophobic, which subsequently enhances the attachment between the cell and micelles. Consequently, the thermosensitive properties of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA will not only enhance cellular uptake, but also increase drug release at lesion sites like tumor or inflammation.37

The core–shell nanoparticles with a LCST close to body temperature may be employed to control drug delivery by heating and cooling the local microenvironment of the nanoparticles. To elucidate the thermosensitive self-assembly behavior from the block polymer P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12 in simulated physiological conditions, the UV-vis transmittance of the copolymer micelles in different PBS media was determined. The LCST values decreased with increasing pH, 36.1°C and 33.9°C at pH 1.4 and 7.4, respectively, while it is 40.0°C in aqueous solution. The temperature feature is meaningful for keeping drug in vivo circulation and release at lesion tissues where the temperature is above normal body temperature. The lower LCST values may be due to the higher ionic strength of the PBS solution, which would promote the formation of intramolecular or intermolecular hydrogen bonds between PNIPAM chains, and interfere with the hydrogen bonding interactions between PNIPAM chains and water molecules, thus resulting in large aggregates of micelles and a hydrophobic contribution to the decreased LCST.38

The thermosensitive micellization behavior of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA block copolymers in D2O solution was also observed by 1H NMR spectra, as shown in Figure 2. Compared with the shift signals of the block polymer in DCCl3, it is clear from Figure 2(a) that the shift signals of the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) chains at 25°C appear at 1.13 (–CH(CH3)2) and 3.99 ppm (–CH(CH3)2), an almost unchanged 1H NMR spectrum in D2O at 25°C. However, the PLA resonance signals at around 1.55 and 5.06–5.21 ppm in D2O decreased due plausibly to suppressed molecular motion of the aggregated hydrophobic cores. Consequently, it is inferred that PLA molecule chains and P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) as side chains constitute the core and shell of the block copolymer micelles, respectively. When the medium temperature was increased to 45°C (above the LCST), the isopropyl characteristic chemical signals at 3.99 and 1.13 ppm in P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) segments were remarkably reduced or disappear due to the increased PNIPAM hydrophobicity. In particular, the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) chains are dehydrated and collapsed, resulting in changes in the 1H NMR spectrum of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA (Figure 2(b)). Therefore, the polymer micelles are converted into a compact core–shell structure composed of a PLA core and a collapsed P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) shell. The thermotriggered micellization behavior can be used for the exchange of substance such as drugs between the core and the external environment.

sec.title: Morphology and size of the control and drug-loaded copolymer micelles
sec.p: It is important for polymer micelles to be smaller than 200 nm for drug carrier applications since this size can avoid glomerular filtration in human applications.5 Therefore, the morphology and the size of the drug-loaded copolymer micelles, including the thermotriggered micellization, were investigated by TEM and DLS measurements, as depicted in Table 2 and Figure 3. The morphology and size of the block copolymer micelles were dependent on their concentration in aqueous solution at room temperature. When the concentration was 250 mg L−1 in aqueous solution, the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-b-PLA12 copolymer formed irregular spherical micelles with tails, and the average particle diameter was about 54.2 nm (Figure 3(a)). Therefore, the micelles are not very symmetrical and stable.

caption.p: TEM morphologies of the blank P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-b-PLA12 copolymer micelle solutions at the concentration of (a) 250 and (b) 800 mg L−1 at room temperature, (c) 250 mg L−1 at 45°C, and (d) drug-loaded polymer micelles. The insets show DLS histograms of particle size distribution at corresponding temperature (the copolymer concentration is 800 mg L−1).
TEM: transmission electron microscope; NIPAM: N-isopropylacrylamide; DMAM: N,N-dimethylacrylamide; DLS: dynamic light scattering.

sec.p: As the copolymer solution concentrations are increased to 800 mg L−1, they self-assemble and form well-dispersed regularly spherical micelles as individual nanoparticles, with an average particle size of ca. 64.3 nm (Figure 3(b)). The increase in the particle size may be ascribed to stronger intermicellar hydrophobic associations in a highly concentrated solution, leading to the formation of larger micelle aggregates. After loading prednisone, the size of the spherical-shaped micelles is increased (Figure 3(d)), which coincides with the change in the Dh (hydrodynamic diameter by DLS) of drug-loaded micelles (Table 2). The Dh range of these drug-loaded micelles was from 120 to 180 nm, a relatively narrow size distribution, making them less susceptible to clearance by the reticuloendothelial system. The morphology and size of the block copolymer micelles exhibit a temperature dependency. Above LCST, the polymer micelles seem to be more stable with regular spherical morphology and slightly lowered particle size from about 54.2 (Figure 3(a)) to 53.5 nm (Figure 3(c)). This phenomenon was ascribed to more complete micellization of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA and the shrinkage of PNIPAM chains above LCST, while at room temperature the micelles are formed mainly by the coiling and collapse of single PLA chains as cores, and P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) segments serving as hydrophilic stabilizer as shells. This conclusion could be made from DLS determinations (insets in Figure 3). The copolymer micelles have different morphologies and size distributions at the two temperatures. The Dh of the micelles at 25°C (below LCST, Figure 3(a)) was in the range of 75–263 nm centered at 138.2 nm while at 45°C (above LCST, Figure 3(c)), the micelle size distribution was from 62 to 185 nm with the mean size of about 107.5 nm. The latter gives smaller Dh and narrower Dh distribution than the former, signifying temperature-dependent size and size distribution. The micellar size decreased with increasing range mass ratios of DMAM to NIPAM as well as P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) to PLA. This alteration may be due to the chain lengths, which produce different hydrophilic–hydrophobic balances and agglomeration behaviors. The Dh detected by DLS was larger than the size determined by TEM; this difference in micellar sizes may be attributed to the hydrodynamic diameter of the micelles in aqueous solutions, while the latter morphological micelle sizes in the solid state, and the shrinkage of the hydrophilic shell of the micelles during TEM sample preparation may decrease the micellar size.39

sec.title: TGA, XRD, and zeta-potential characterizations of drug-loaded micelles
sec.p: Prednisone-loaded P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-b-PLA micelles were characterized by TGA, XRD, and zeta potential, as shown in Tables 2 and 3 as well as in Figure 4. Both the control and prednisone-loaded micelles formulations have negative surface charges at room temperature in a PBS solution at pH 7.4, and the increase in the absolute values of zeta potential corresponds to the decrease in their CMC values. The micelles did not aggregate in the presence of FBS, which was attributed to the hydrophilic nature and negative charge of the micelle surfaces.

caption.p: Glass transition temperatures (Tg) and melting points (Tm) of prednisone, blank micelles, and prednisone-loaded micelles.

fn.p: NIPAM: N-isopropylacrylamide; DMAM: N,N-dimethylacrylamide; PLA: poly(d,l-lactide).

caption.p: (a) TGA curves and (b) XRD patterns of (1) free prednisone, (2) (PNIPAM-co-DMAM) 91-b-PLA12 micelles, and (3) prednisone-loaded (PNIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12 micelles.
TGA: thermal gravimetric analysis; XRD: X-ray diffraction; PNIPAM: poly(N-isopropylacrylamide); DMAM: N,N-dimethylacrylamide.

sec.p: The physical status of prednisone inside the micelles was determined from DSC data tabulated in Table 3. Free prednisone produces a melting point of 242°C, which was not observed in the prednisone-loaded micelles, indicating that prednisone molecules are trapped in an amorphous phase. Blank polymer micelles exhibit two glass transition temperatures: 147°C from P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) block and 57°C from PLA block. After loading of prednisone, Tg of PLA block increased to 64°C while the Tg of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) block remains unchanged. This suggests that prednisone molecules are located in the core of the micelles. The increase in Tg of PLA block may be due to the hydrophobic interactions between PLA block and prednisone molecules.

In the TGA and XRD spectra of the free prednisone and the prednisone-loaded micelles (Figure 4(a)), the free prednisone did not have any mass loss below 240°C and then gradually decomposed at 600°C, the mass retention was approximately 31%. The PNIPAM-co-DMAM91-b-PLA12 micelles had two main mass losses: the one below ~100°C was due to the removal or vaporation of small molecular substances, such as unreacted monomers and residual solvent. The other was in the range from 355°C to 425°C ascribed to the rapid degradation of the polymer backbone. The TGA curve of prednisone-loaded micelles is between the two, further confirming that prednisone molecules are molecularly distributed in the micelles. The crystalline prednisone had a number of sharp peaks in the XRD spectrum, as shown in Figure 4(b), while the prednisone-loaded micelles produced the same XRD patterns as those by amorphous PNIPAM-co-DMAM91-b-PLA12 micelles. These data further corroborate that amorphous prednisone molecules were encapsulated in the micelles.

sec.title: Cytotoxicity tests
sec.p: To the assess cytotoxicity, the MTT assay study was carried out with P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-OH and prednisone-loaded and unloaded P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-b-PLA12 micelles by determining the viability or the cyclical metabolic activity of L929 cells incubated in a humidified condition at 37°C with 5% CO2.40 As shown in Figure 5(a), the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-b-PLA12 block copolymer micelles were less cytotoxic to L929 cells below 500 mg L−1 with the cell viability of 88%–122% after incubation for 24 hours, except for lower cell viability of ~65% at 100 mg L−1 (p < 0.05). More than 100% cell viability suggests that the copolymer micelles make for the cell proliferation and promote cell division and growth. The cell viability of the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-OH random copolymer was relatively low and decreased as the concentration increases. The low cytotoxicity of the block copolymer micelles may be ascribed to the incorporation of the biocompatible PLA segments. Interestingly, the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-b-PLA12 block copolymer micelles give rise to increased cell viability as the concentration was increased up to 500 mg L−1. Similar findings were also reported by Vihola et al.41 For 100 mg L−1 block copolymer micelles, the effect of culture time on the cell viability is depicted in Figure 5(b). The cell viability of the block copolymer micelles increased with time at the same dose, exhibiting very high biocompatibility. The lowest cell viability appeared at incubation for 24 hours, indicating the occurrence of a cumulative cytotoxic effect when the polymer micelles were in contact with the L929 cells. After 48 h, the polymeric micelles exhibit no cytotoxicity with the cell viability more than 100%. The cell survival percentage on the fifth day decreases by about 13% compared with the fourth day as a result of the periodicity of cell growth and proliferation.

caption.p: Cytotoxicity of the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-OH micelles to L929 cells, blank and prednisone-loaded P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)82-b-PLA12 micelles at (a) micellar concentration and (b) various time intervals (the micellar concentration: 100 mg L−1) determined by MTT assay; morphological images (100×) of L929 cells for (c) control and (d) the copolymer micelle with concentrations of 100 mg L−1 after incubation of 24 h under inverted light microscope.
NIPAM: N-isopropylacrylamide; DMAM: N,N-dimethylacrylamide; MTT: methyl thiazolyl tetrazolium; PLA: poly(D,L-lactide).

sec.p: Taking into account the low cell survival at the micellar concentration of 100 mg L−1, cell morphological analyses were conducted to evaluate the cytotoxicity. As shown in Figure 5(d) it is evident that the number and dispersity of mouse fibroblasts adhering to the surface of the micelle are very close to those on the negative control except that tiny cells contract into a round shape, a normal phenomenon during cell division and proliferation (comparing Figure 5(c) with (d)). The cells themselves stretch sufficiently and take on healthy spindle-shaped, fusiform, or triangular topologies.

However, the cytotoxicity of micelles was not equal to that of drug-loaded micelles, as shown in Figure 5(a) and (b). Clearly, the cytotoxicity of the prednisone-loaded micelles was a little more cytotoxic within the whole concentration range, which correlated with some in vitro drug release.42 With respect to the time-dependent cell viability, the drug-loaded polymer micelle shows slightly increased cytotoxicity after 48-h incubation. Despite that, the cell survival percentage was over 80% which indicated low cytotoxicity.

Overall, there was no significant difference among the cytocompatibility of the blank and drug-loaded copolymer micelles. The copolymer micelles have low cytotoxicity to the L929 cells with the concentration up to 500 mg L−1, and consequently, they can be practically regarded as a safe drug delivery carrier in biomedical applications.

Based on the thermally responsive cytotoxicity of prednisone-loaded micelles data, the free prednisone cytotoxicity was high at 37°C and 45°C, while prednisone-loaded micelles cytotoxicity was high at 45°C (above LCST) and low at 37°C (below LCST) (Figure 6(a)). The higher cytotoxicity of the prednisone-loaded micelles above the LCST may be caused by enhanced drug release and concomitant accelerated uptake of the prednisone-loaded micelles by the cells.31

caption.p: (a) Cytotoxicity of prednisone-loaded micelles at (1) 37°C and (2) 45°C and free prednisone at (3) 37°C and (4) 45°C on L929 cells (the copolymer micellar concentration of 500 mg L−1, and a comparison of drug-loaded micelles with free drug at the same concentration of 5 mg L−1); (b) plating efficiency of L929 cells exposed to either free or micelles-released prednisone solutions versus the prednisone concentration in the solution after culture for 48 h.

sec.p: The in vitro bioactivity of model drug after loading was further determined by a PE versus prednisone concentration for the L929 cells treated with free prednisone solutions or with prednisone released from the micelles, as depicted in Figure 6(b). PE as a measure of the number of colonies originating from single cells was determined by the following formulae

The PEs are calculated based on the number of cells plated in the culture dishes. It is clear that the PE for both solutions has similar prednisone concentration dependence, with little difference in the bioactivity of prednisone after loading, which clearly demonstrates that the prednisone released from the micelles possesses the same activity against the proliferative potential of the L929 cells. This confirmed the usefulness of the thermotriggered block copolymer micelles.

sec.title: Controlled release and release kinetics of prednisone drug
sec.p: It is of primary importance to understand the release behavior of prednisone from polymer micelles as it may provide a foundation for minimizing systemic leakage of the drug before it reaches the target site. The controlled drug release behavior for prednisone-loaded P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12 block copolymer micelles is measured in distilled water at room temperature and 45°C, as well as under simulated physiological conditions (Figure 7).

caption.p: Drug release behavior of prednisone-loaded P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12 block copolymer micelles (a) at 25 and 45°C as well as (b) under simulated physiological conditions (37°C, PBS solutions of pH 1.4 and 7.4).
NIPAM: N-isopropylacrylamide; DMAM: N,N-dimethylacrylamide; PBS: phosphate-buffered saline; PLA: poly(D,L-lactide).

sec.p: At each temperature, the prednisone drug release profile had a large increase followed by a slow release rate. At 25°C (below the LCST), only a small amount of the encapsulated drug was released due to the better stability of the micelles, as more than 80% of the drug remained in the micelles. However, when the release medium temperature was increased to 45°C (above the LCST), the drug release rate increased due to temperature-induced structural alterations of the polymer micelles. The P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) shells become more hydrophobic above the LCST, which led to the deformation and shrinkage of the micellar structure and the prednisone to diffuse out of the micelles. Within 24 hours 53.5% of the drug was released from the micelles, which indicated that the block copolymer micelles have a very strong thermotriggered drug release property. This is beneficial for activity at the high temperature associated with disease sites. It was noted that although the temperature often has beneficial effects on the diffusion rate, the temperature effect is not a predominant factor because of the micellar stability after the hydrophobic drug is encapsulated into the hydrophobic core. However, the effect of temperature on the diffusion rate cannot be ignored when the micelle shell becomes hydrophobic above the LCST. Since the rate of diffusion is directly proportional to the temperature, namely, higher temperature results in faster rate of diffusion, the high amount of drug release is also due to the additional temperature-induced diffusion effect at higher temperatures.

To further prove the potential of the micelles for drug delivery applications, the prednisone drug release behavior in stimulated bodily environments (PBS solutions with pH 1.4 (stimulated gastric fluids (SGFs)) and 7.4 (stimulated intestinal fluids (SIFs) and blood plasma, 37°C) was investigated, as shown in Figure 7. The initial drug release was faster at pH 7.4 than at pH 1.4, and that the rate was between that at 45°C and 25°C in aqueous solution. This might be attributed to the deformation of micelles in an approximate neutral environment and the increased micelle stability in an acid medium. The initial burst release was ascribed to the release of the drug molecules loaded in the shell and corona or deposited on the surface of the micelles or at the interface between the micelle core and shells since the drug might form hydrogen bonds with the amide group of P(NIPAM-co-DMAM) segments.43 On the other hand, the special properties of the thermosensitive copolymer as well as the strong interactions between the drug and the hydrophobic PLA chains may prolong the drug release time, even at temperatures above the LCST. After injection of the micelles to targeted sites at a temperature above the LCST or body temperature, these micelles would undergo a phase transition and the drug concentration would increase quickly.

To understand the drug transport mechanism and environmental factors involved with the temperature-triggered hydrophobic drug release behavior, the Ritger–Peppas model44–47 was used to elucidate the prednisone drug transport mechanism from the P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)91-b-PLA12 micelle by fitting these kinetic data for the onset stage of drug release (the model is valid only for the first 60% of the fractional release)

where Mt and M∞ are the total amount of drug released at time t and equilibrium time, respectively; k is a kinetic constant that measures the drug release rate and is calculated by measuring the intercepts of the lines by the least squares method; and n represents an exponent characteristic of the release mechanism. When n is less than or equal to 0.5, the drug release is controlled by Fickian diffusion mechanism. When the value is between 0.5 and 1, an anomalous diffusion occurs. Drug release follows a diffusion mechanism approaching zero-order release as the n value equals to 1. This model can be considered as a general model for drug release kinetics from nanosystems, slabs, spheres, cylinders, and disks (tablets), regardless of the release mechanism.

Linear regression analyses using the drug release versus release time data from Figure 7 are provided in Table 4. In aqueous solution at 25°C and 45°C as well as in PBS solution of pH 7.4 (37°C), the n values are greater than 0.5, implying that the release modes of prednisone in the micelles deviate from Fickian diffusion control mechanism and are controlled by an anomalous diffusion. Since more drugs are continuously delivered from micelles within a short time, there is a higher bioavailability under these conditions. In PBS solution of pH 1.4 (37°C), the drug release is primarily controlled by Fickian diffusion. Drug transport mechanism analyses reveal that the drug release behavior may be mediated by the structural changes of the micelles caused by temperature- or environment-induced diffusion.

sec.p: The micelles exhibit higher prednisone diffusion coefficients at 45°C than at 25°C in both early-time and late-time approximation equations due to the temperature-induced structural alterations of micelles and the temperature effect on diffusion rates. It was noted that the DL values were always lower than DE values at both 45°C and 25°C, indicating that drug release rates decrease with the release time. The preliminary kinetic modeling confirmed that the copolymer micelles can control drug release behavior and improve bioavailability via temperature or environmental changes.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A new thermosensitive P(NIPAM-co-DMAM)-PLA copolymer was designed and synthesized by using a simple free radical copolymerization route. These copolymers self-assemble into micelles (containing prednisone) with regular spherical shapes with diameters less than 73 nm. The micelles exhibit a LCST range from 32°C to 47°C, depending on the composition of the copolymer and its environment. The CMC values were in the range from 5.50 to 7.20 mg L−1, and stable at high dilution. The blank and prednisone-loaded micelles had hydrodynamic diameters less than 180 nm. No significant cytotoxicity was observed for the blank and prednisone-loaded copolymer micelles up to 500 mg L−1. This indicated that the drug-loaded micelles retain their biological activity at the temperature and physiological conditions of the human body. The thermocontrolled drug release from the copolymer micelles, in various media as well as the in vitro drug bioactivity after loading, indicated effective target therapy against lesion tissues. These copolymers could be utilized as potential carriers for the effective encapsulation and controlled release of drugs and other bioactive agents.
